Title: Randomised Controlled Trial of Lateral Lymph Node Involvement in Rectal Cancer

Background: The significance of enlarged lateral lymph nodes (LLN) in rectal cancer recurrence, metastasis, and organ preservation remains debated. This study evaluates LLN involvement in patients with rectal adenocarcinoma.

Methods: A post hoc analysis of the OPRA trial, a multicenter randomised controlled trial, was conducted. Patients with rectal cancer received total neoadjuvant therapy (TNT) followed by total mesorectal excision or watch-and-wait management. Eligibility included patients with locally advanced rectal cancer. The primary outcome was disease recurrence, measured over a follow-up period. Randomisation was performed centrally, with allocation concealment. Blinding was not specified. 

Results: Of 324 patients, 57 (18%) had visible LLN (LLN+) on baseline MRI. After TNT, LLN disappeared in 30 (53%) of these patients. Disease recurrence in LLN was rare, occurring in 3.5% of LLN+ and 0.4% of LLN− patients. All patients with LLN recurrence also had distant metastasis. Organ preservation was significantly lower in patients with LLN ≥ 4 mm on restaging MRI (P = 0.013). No significant differences in local recurrence or metastasis rates were found between LLN+ vs. LLN− and LLN ≥ 7 mm vs. < 7 mm on baseline MRI. LLN dissection was performed in 3 patients; 2 died of distant metastasis.

Interpretation: LLN involvement is not associated with increased recurrence or metastasis, but persistence of LLN ≥ 4 mm post-TNT negatively impacts rectum preservation. LLN dissection benefits few patients. Trial registration: [Number]. Funding: [Source].
